repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
These were previously getting missed. Added code to specialize them
and tests to prove it.

Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3142
Also fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3460 - (seems related enough to go in the same PR)

comment_data.body: This should better read `cimport` in a `.pxd` file. While `import cython` is accepted as well, it's confusing here because `.pxd` files are purely compile-time evaluated.

I'm wondering: shouldn't re-evaluation of the annotation result in the same type again? (I.e. does it hurt to do that?)

OTOH, maybe there should be a single point where we apply these annotations, and specialised fused function simply shouldn't have to care about them at all any more?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -220,6 +220,10 @@ def _specialize_function_args(self, args, fused_to_specific):
                 arg.type = arg.type.specialize(fused_to_specific)
                 if arg.type.is_memoryviewslice:
                     arg.type.validate_memslice_dtype(arg.pos)
+                if arg.annotation:
+                    # TODO might be nice if annotations were specialized instead?
+                    # (Or might be hard to do reliably)

@@ -37,6 +40,7 @@ def cpfunc(self, arg):
         >>> TestCls().cpfunc(2)
         'int'
         """
+        loca = arg

comment_data.body: Yes. I think I wanted a different name to catch in the debugger when preparing this. It'll still work like this but I'll fix it if other changes are needed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -37,6 +40,7 @@ def cpfunc(self, arg):
         >>> TestCls().cpfunc(2)
         'int'
         """
+        loca = arg

@@ -37,6 +40,7 @@ def cpfunc(self, arg):
         >>> TestCls().cpfunc(2)
         'int'
         """
+        loca = arg

@@ -1,6 +1,9 @@
+import cython
+
 ctypedef fused NotInPy:
     int
     float
 
 cdef class TestCls:
+    @cython.locals(loca = NotInPy)

comment_data.body: It's the same one in a different place - otherwise it'd be broken :) Thanks
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,6 +1,9 @@
+import cython
+
 ctypedef fused NotInPy:
     int
     float
 
 cdef class TestCls:
+    @cython.locals(loca = NotInPy)

comment_data.body:
Re-evaluation of an annotation will give the fused type (again). However, in a fused function that ends up overwriting the specialized type. Originally I'd tried to do it by looking if the annotation gave was a subtype of the fused type.
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/6a30fecff5decdf20029763afea6183de3177dc3/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L1683
The trouble with that is that it breaks for Python objects (since the assigned type starts as a Python object so the annotation never gets applied).

I don't think we can just ignore annotations in a fused specialization because I don't think the function knows its a fused specialization.

We can't use use `fused_to_specific` because that's applied after `analyse_declarations` https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/daf7e9534021e513a1c7da90732bb1e1b9638671/Cython/Compiler/FusedNode.py#L103-L106 and is also seems to be explicitly turned off when analysing the argument types https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/daf7e9534021e513a1c7da90732bb1e1b9638671/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L2920

It definitely seems like getting types from annotations could be done better (i.e. in one place) - they're a bit scattered all over the place. That's obviously a bigger change
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -220,6 +220,10 @@ def _specialize_function_args(self, args, fused_to_specific):
                 arg.type = arg.type.specialize(fused_to_specific)
                 if arg.type.is_memoryviewslice:
                     arg.type.validate_memslice_dtype(arg.pos)
+                if arg.annotation:
+                    # TODO might be nice if annotations were specialized instead?
+                    # (Or might be hard to do reliably)

@@ -17,17 +17,20 @@ def func1(self, arg: 'NotInPy'):
         >>> TestCls().func1(2)
         'int'
         """
+        loc: 'NotInPy' = arg
         return cython.typeof(arg)
 
     if cython.compiled:
-        @cython.locals(arg = NotInPy)  # NameError in pure Python
+        @cython.locals(arg = NotInPy,
+                       loc = NotInPy)  # NameError in pure Python

comment_data.body: It fixes a bug, let's keep it like it is for now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -220,6 +220,10 @@ def _specialize_function_args(self, args, fused_to_specific):
                 arg.type = arg.type.specialize(fused_to_specific)
                 if arg.type.is_memoryviewslice:
                     arg.type.validate_memslice_dtype(arg.pos)
+                if arg.annotation:
+                    # TODO might be nice if annotations were specialized instead?
+                    # (Or might be hard to do reliably)

commit.message:
Specialize fused function local variables specified with pure-python

These were previously getting missed. Added code to specialize them
and tests to prove it.

Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3142

Fixed an issue with pure fused types containing object

Instead annotation typing is turned off

Increase version for pure_fused test

(For the python mode)
Reformat a comment to make it clearer where it belongs.

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Specialize fused function local variables specified with pure-python
